author: normative

text: We could probably have a tedious semantic sidebar about whether there’s a salient distinction between “morally justified” and “morally correct”, but probably not to any useful end, so sure. As long as we’re agreed that’s not compatible with indifference to facts.
author: normative

text: And that’s a “yes” on any plausible view.  If you believe a fellow subway passenger is pickpocketing people, it might be right to alert the police.  But not if your only basis for that (sincere) belief is some combination of racial stereotypes and “he looked shifty.”
author: normative

text: The relevant question is whether there’s such a thing as culpable epistemic irresponsibility. As in: your harmful action would have been justified by the truth of your belief X, if true, but the belief that X is itself so irresponsible or ill-supported that it isn’t.
author: normative

text: On any plausible view, that’s a “no”, whether or not you want to make a distinction between “morally justified” and “morally correct” actions, and whether or not your standard for either of those things is consequentialist.
author: normative

text: I don’t want to do deontology versus consequentialism in tweets, but happily it’s not necessary, because it’s mostly a separate topic.  The relevant question isn’t whether you’re responsible for all consequences of your actions independently of their foreseeability.
author: normative

text: But, to extend the analogy, the judgement that someone is acting rationally (though not in the way they have most reason to act) typically depends on a second order judgment that the beliefs are themselves rational to hold given the available information.
author: normative

text: What you mean is that you can act morally while doing something that is not morally good, in the same way that you can be acting rationally (given your beliefs) while doing things you in fact have no reason to do (and strong reasons not to do). Sure, to a point.
author: normative

text: I think some minimal epistemic due diligence is morally required.  People circulate all sorts of ludicrously false, inflammatory information that they’ve made no effort to check. I’d call that culpably negligent even if they don’t know it to be false.

text: Obviously the core game experience is the player’s experience, and you wouldn’t expect designers to sacrifice that for watchability, but I bet many games could be tweaked at little cost on that front to make them more engaging for... let’s call it a “participatory viewer.”
author: normative

text: How easily can what’s going on be followed by someone walking into the room in medias res, or dipping in and out?  Can that observer glean enough to make useful suggestions—say, if the player is stuck on a puzzle?
author: normative

text: Is narrative conveyed through dialogue or lengthy text?  How legible are choices made with the controller to an observer (even when it’s adequate clear to the player what they’re doing)?  Are there significant choices paced to permit observer input?
author: normative

text: It seems like there are lots of choices designers can make that would make a game more or less enjoyable for a non-player in the room without fundamentally altering the nature of the game.  And my sense is this isn’t something designers consciously focus on too much.
author: normative

text: In those cases, the difference in appeal to the non-player observer comes down to pretty fundamental mechanics. I doubt there’s a way to make Dark Souls fun to watch (except in the case of an inhumanly skilled player) without altering it beyond recognition.  BUT...

text: Pedantry ahead: it’s significant that this rule uses the phrase “single pull of the trigger” when the statute says “a single function of the trigger.” If the law said “pull” it would be a closer call, but a semi with a bump stock still only fires once per trigger “function”.

text: Production there is pretty obviously testimonial, because you’re requiring the recipient to use their own knowledge to pick out the messages responsive to the request for you. You’re conscripting them to add info that may not even be apparent from the produced document itself.

text: Formally, this may be a legitimate claim given the letter’s objection to the broad language of a request for “documents concerning” certain matters. To pick an absurd extreme, imagine a demand for all correspondence related to a criminal conspiracy.
author: normative

text: Of course, you don’t have to actually be guilty of anything to plead the 5th, but it does have to be the case that the production would “tend to incriminate”—that is, plausibly create an appearance of guilt, even if it’s a false one.
author: normative

text: That is, you normally can’t invoke the 5th to avoid a subpoena for specific documents, even if the *contents* of the documents would incriminate you, unless *the fact that you even have the documents* would be incriminating. (“Produce your original copy of the ransom letter...”)
author: normative

text: Second, and more importantly, the Fifth Amendment only applies to the production of documents when *the production itself*—the fact that the person has access to the material described—would be “testimonial” and potentially incriminating.
author: normative

text: Courts  like bright line rules. But the two obvious bright line rules here are “confirmation required, no exceptions”—which is both impractical for real emergencies and inconsistent with historical practice—and a deferential rule that makes the Appointments Clause easy to hack.

text: He just has to wait seven months, nominate someone so unacceptable that even the GOP-controlled Senate won’t confirm them, then repeat the process. But, of course, we can’t know in advance whether he’ll actually do that. So when is Whitaker no longer “temporary”?

text: Ditto with “temporary.”  As I noted in this blog post at Cato, the way the FVRA clock for presidentially filled vacancies works, Trump could in theory probably keep Whitaker in place for the rest of his term if that’s what he decides he wants to do.

text: Trouble is, it’s hard to see how a court distinguishes this case without opening a can of worms.  *Technically* Sessions resigned, even though we all understand he was de facto fired. Do the courts get sucked into making ad hoc determinations about which exigencies are “real”?
author: normative

text: But I’m pretty sure the vast majority of the cases being cited represent genuine exigencies: the officer is sick or dies or resigns unexpectedly.  They don’t present the problem of a president deliberately gaming the system to replace a confirmed official with a crony.

text: Here’s why this seems tricky for the courts: there’s clearly tons of precedent for non-confirmed officers stepping in to a superior’s role briefly in cases of genuine exigency. It would be hugely impractical if offices had to go vacant whenever a cabinet secretary has surgery.

text: But by the time these conversations play out you’ve been inhabiting Arthur Morgan for a couple dozen hours. So that’s their hook: They can make you feel qualms about *what you’re doing to Arthur* as you discover he has a conscience & feels badly about the things you make him do.

text: The genius here is that it wouldn’t really be effective if they tried to make the player feel qualms directly about what they’re doing to some thinly-sketched homesteader NPC or simulated deer. None of them are realized enough to get the player-implicating hooks in.

text: The logical upshot of this theory is, instead, that the laws of the country where the parents were born determine whether the child is a U.S. citizen, and whether they’re lawfully resident or not should be irrelevant.
author: normative

text: The political argument we’re hearing is that the Wong Kim Ark precedent is fine as far as children of legal permanent residents goes, but doesn’t require citizenship for children of unauthorized immigrants. But the legal theory being invoked doesn’t support that conclusion.
author: normative

text: The U.S. currently lets children born abroad inherit the U.S. citizenship of either parent, but that’s a matter of statute and has changed over time. Different countries have different rules.
author: normative

text: The theory also would seem to make the application of the U.S. Constitution depend on the laws of *other countries*, since whether the child is eligible for foreign citizenship (and therefore supposedly not fully under U.S. “jurisdiction”) would depend on foreign law.
author: normative

text: Wong Kim Ark’s parents, after all, were Chinese subjects. That they were legally resident in the U.S. had no bearing on their allegiance to China, which on this theory is supposed to be the decisive factor. The theory provides no basis for distinguishing WKA, only reversing it.

text: But on that theory, why would it exclude only children of “illegal immigrants” (a category that didn’t really exist when the 14th Amendment was ratified)? Why not non-citizen legal permanent residents and dual nationals also?

text: So it is *not remotely* mysterious or incongruous that someone who routinely manages their claustrophobia to fly would be particularly wary of flying after many anxious & sleepless nights to relive a harrowing experience of feeling trapped in front of a national audience.
author: normative

text: ...that I had to repeatedly assure flight attendants I didn’t need medical attention. Some people are so extremely claustrophobic they never fly. But normally, whether an anxiety like that is managable or not is contextual.
author: normative

text: Once, I tried flying cross-country in a rear window seat while I was a little sick & feeling stressed for various reasons. It set off a panic attack & one of the most miserable few hours of my life. I managed to avoid making a scene, but was so flushed & sweaty...
author: normative

text: Ok, because this silly flying thing seems to have legs: I fly all the time, for work and vacation. I’m mildly claustrophobic, but normally this is no problem. I take an aisle seat, put on music, & do some breathing exercises if I start getting anxious. It’s fine.

text: There is nothing very mysterious about someone who normally overcomes her claustrophobia being more worried about taking a cross-country flight, after many anxious & sleepless nights, to relive a traumatic experience of feeling trapped on national television.

text: There’s no reason to believe she lied if you understand how claustrophobia & anxiety work. People with claustrophobia overcome anxiety about flying all the time. But other stressors can make a panic attack much more likely.
